After this opened Job his mouth, and cursed his day.
And Job spake, and said,<RF>spake: Heb. answered<Rf>
Let the day perish wherein I was born, and the night <FI>in which<Fi> it was said, There is a man child conceived.
Let that day be darkness; let not God regard it from above, neither let the light shine upon it.

Let darkness and the shadow of death stain it; let a cloud dwell upon it; let the blackness of the day terrify it.<RF>stain: or, challenge<Rf><RF>let the…: or, let them terrify it, as those who have a bitter day<Rf>

As <FI>for<Fi> that night, let darkness seize upon it; let it not be joined unto the days of the year, let it not come into the number of the months.<RF>let it not be…: or, let it not rejoice among the days<Rf>
Lo, let that night be solitary, let no joyful voice come therein.
Let them curse it that curse the day, who are ready to raise up their mourning.<RF>their…: or, leviathan<Rf>
Let the stars of the twilight thereof be dark; let it look for light, but <FI>have<Fi> none; neither let it see the dawning of the day:<RF>the dawning…: Heb. the eyelids of the morning<Rf>
Because it shut not up the doors of my <FI>mother's<Fi> womb, nor hid sorrow from mine eyes.<CM>
Why died I not from the womb? <FI>why<Fi> did I <FI>not<Fi> give up the ghost when I came out of the belly?
Why did the knees prevent me? or why the breasts that I should suck?
For now should I have lain still and been quiet, I should have slept: then had I been at rest,
With kings and counsellors of the earth, which built desolate places for themselves;
Or with princes that had gold, who filled their houses with silver:
Or as an hidden untimely birth I had not been; as infants <FI>which<Fi> never saw light.
There the wicked cease <FI>from<Fi> troubling; and there the weary be at rest.<RF>weary: Heb. wearied in strength<Rf>
<FI>There<Fi> the prisoners rest together; they hear not the voice of the oppressor.
The small and great are there; and the servant <FI>is<Fi> free from his master.<CM>
Wherefore is light given to him that is in misery, and life unto the bitter <FI>in<Fi> soul;
Which long for death, but it <FI>cometh<Fi> not; and dig for it more than for hid treasures;<RF>long: Heb. wait<Rf>
Which rejoice exceedingly, <FI>and<Fi> are glad, when they can find the grave?
<FI>Why is light given<Fi> to a man whose way is hid, and whom God hath hedged in?
For my sighing cometh before I eat, and my roarings are poured out like the waters.<RF>I eat: Heb. my meat<Rf>
For the thing which I greatly feared is come upon me, and that which I was afraid of is come unto me.<RF>the thing…: Heb. I feared a fear, and it came upon me<Rf>
I was not in safety, neither had I rest, neither was I quiet; yet trouble came.<CM>
